Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Paleoceanographic Analysis of an Ancient Epeiric Sea
Award.AbstractNarration:
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Integrated Paleoceanographic Analysis of the Late Paleozoic Midcontinent Sea

Achim Herrmann, Arizona State University. EAR-1052988
Thomas Algeo, Univ. Cincinnatti, EAR-1053449
James Barrick, Texas Tech University, EAR-1053042
Bernd Haupt, Penn State University, EAR-1052998

ABSTRACT
Due to different environmental conditions and paleogeographic settings of ancient times, some past sedimentary environments have no good modern analogues. For instance, previous interpretations of environmental conditions of black shale deposition centered on applying modern analogs of coastal upwelling or ?Black-Sea type? silled basin topographies. However, a superestuarine circulation model has been proposed recently to explain the abundant and widespread Paleozoic black shale deposits of Midcontinent North America. It is the purpose of this research project to use an interdisciplinary approach to investigate paleoceanographic conditions during the deposition of Pennsylvanian cyclothems of Midcontinent North America and to test the ?superestuarine circulation hypothesis?. This work is a comprehensive data-model synthesis study and geochemical proxies (strontium and oxygen isotopes of biogenic apatite; bulk major- and trace-element abundance data, TOC-TIC-S concentrations, and petrographic data) will be compared to biofacies distribution patterns and to results of numerical ocean circulation models.

Funding provides research opportunities for undergraduates at several universities and will support one PhD thesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative research study. The model-data integration that we were going to attempt for the Late Pennsylvanian Midcontinent Sea simulations was the first of its kind at the time of funding support. As such, this proposal was fairly “high-risk” as this didn’t allow on drawing experience from previous studies that have done this sort of integrated paleoceanographic work and demonstrated that this approach will lead to the expected results. As one reviewer pointed out, “it is entirely possible that this project could result in defining deficiencies in currently existing numerical models.”

Much of the geologic record of Earth history and the accumulation of natural resources occurred in epeiric seas rather than in the global ocean or continent-margin settings. The boundary conditions and environmental characteristics conducive to widespread benthic anoxia in ancient epeiric seas are not well understood, in part due to a paucity of modern analogues. This study was aimed to gain knowledge on how to adopt the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS) to paleoclimate modeling which had to our knowledge not done by start of funding but also building the tools. Initially, this project had several goals after having investigated the options of using the global climate model CCSM 3 versus CCSM 4 during early stages of this project. The PIs decided in favor of CCSM 3. The basic idea was using a global coarse resolution model to define the boundary conditions for the regional model ROMS which includes biogeochemistry but also a variable bathymetry using stretched terrain-following coordinates. This type of coordinates usually being absent in coarse resolution global climate models provides an increased resolution in areas of interest, such as the thermocline and bottom boundary layers. Due to a reduced budget the focus was shifted towards ROMS and building tools that can be used to use the bathymetry and forcing data from global climate models, regardless whether they were set up for past or present climates. The suite of tools developed ranges from Matlab to Unix/Linux scripts that can be used to create regional high-resolution paleobathymetries in SeaGrid and GridBuilder. The developed and automated tools then use the smoothed and calibrated regional bathymetries and extract the necessary boundary conditions and forcing fields from the global models to run ROMS. The tools have been tested and work for both, CCSM3 and CCSM4 model output.

A follow up study is underway to refine the tools in order to include an easy streamlined incorporation of sea level change and to test variable river input.
